item.description:
Finishing the prep work for New Rustacean e018.

Have I mentioned lately that I love Rust? Because I really, really do.

item.description:
I‚Äôm extremely excited to be adding a new format to New Rustacean: discussing good crates in the Rust ecosystem. Suggestions wanted!

item.description:
This is a great summary of what I enjoy about Rust: it just lets me get stuff done‚Äîquickly, usually elegantly, and it‚Äôs always speedy:

All the cool kids are writing @rustlang think pieces, so I wrote one too: Rust is about productivity: https://t.co/OPwfWfpVic

‚Äî nrc (@nick_r_cameron ‚Ä¶
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description:
A thing I just learned: cargo doc --open: full, local docs for every dependency your Rust crate has.

Mind. blown.

item.description:
This is fun: Lightning now loads the YAML configuration I defined. Doesn‚Äôt do much of anything with them, but it loads them!

(I‚Äôm developing Lightning totally in public, so you can follow along here.)

item.description: Just had my first experience of writing a lifetime-requiring function in Rust and inherently knowing exactly what lifetimes it needed.

item.description: One of the great joys in programming is when you start to feel even just a little bit fluent in a technology.

item.title: The Itch
item.description: Learning functional programming has been simultaneously wildly new and deeply familiar. It's the answer to questions I've been asking for most of a decade.

item.description: Spent a chunk of the afternoon figuring out how to implement Rust‚Äôs Result type in TypeScript. Pretty cool!

item.description: Two lessons from today‚Äôs Rust spelunking: the library team has done a fantastic job, and we need non-lexical, liveness-based lifetimes. (See this discussion by Niko Matsakis for some of the ideas there and why we need them.)

item.title: Rust and C++ function definitions
item.description:
I just put my finger on one of the (many) reasons Rust reads better than C++: the visual consistency of its function definitions. Compare‚Äî

Rust has:

fn foo() -> i32 { /* implementation */ }
fn bar() -> f32 { /* implementation */ }

C++ has:

int foo() { /* implementation */ }
double bar() { /* implementation */ }

That consistency adds up over many lines of ‚Ä¶
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description:
When I podcast, I don‚Äôt do ‚Äújust news.‚Äù I do ‚Äúnews I MEAN describe how MIR changes the Rust compiler flow‚Äù:

‚ñ∂ New Rustacean News 1: One year and counting‚Äîon Rust a year in, including an overview of how the compiler works

item.title: If-expressions in Rust
item.description:
I love the fact that all if statements in Rust are expressions. It gives you a great deal of expressitivity in the language.

Let‚Äôs contrast with Python (which I love, for the record). In Python, you can do something like this:

some_condition = True
if some_condition:
    a_value = "Yeah!"
else:
    a_value ‚Ä¶
item.dc:creator: Chris Krycho

item.description: Since Rust allows unsafe code, it‚Äôs easy to wonder how necessary it is. The answer: in general, not at all.

item.description: I can think of no more effective an argument for Rust and its memory safety guarantees than the time I spent this weekend hunting down bugs caused by buffer overruns in decades-old C code.

item.title: High- and Low-Level Programming Languages
item.description: It occurred to me while listening to Edwin Brady talk about Idris on the Type Theory Podcast,1 having just spent a few weeks starting to learn Rust: ‚Äúlow-level‚Äù has at least two meanings in software. One is whether something has manual memory management or is garbage collected, reference counted ‚Ä¶
